Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial of Bicruciate-Retaining versus Cruciate-Retaining Total Knee Arthroplasty

Trial_Design.evidence: This parallel-group trial (ClinicalTrials.gov: NCT01966848) randomised 50 patients

Participants.evidence: 50 patients with intact ACLs undergoing TKA

Intervention.evidence: randomised 50 patients with intact ACLs undergoing TKA to receive either bicruciate-retaining or cruciate-retaining TKA

Objective.evidence: This study assesses tibial component migration and patient-reported outcomes.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was maximum total point motion (MTPM) of the tibial component at 2 years

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and patients were blinded to allocation.

Number_Analysed.evidence: RSA data were available for 22 bicruciate-retaining and 23 cruciate-retaining patients, while patient-reported outcomes were available for 24 patients in each group.

Result_Outcome.evidence: No significant difference in MTPM was observed (median MTPM: 0.52 mm vs. 0.42 mm, p = 0.63).

Harms.evidence: Three bicruciate-retaining patients required arthroscopic manipulation, and one sustained a tibial fracture requiring revision.
